romanian.text: When men take wives they stop fearing hell.
A bad workman quarrels with his tools.
A barber learns to shave by shaving fools.
A change of rulers is the joy of fools.
A child is a blessing for any man’s roof.
A clear sky fears not the thunder.
A cunning person’s kiss is like that of a mosquito.
A disease known is half cured.
A dog dies from too much walking , a fool from worrying about other’s business.
A dog doesn’t enter if the door is not open.
A fence with supports is not overthrown by high winds.
A foreigner scratches you where you do not itch.
A foreigner’s pity is like a thorn’s shadow.
A girl in her time is like honey in the comb.
A girl’s honesty is like snow: when it melts the whiteness is no longer seen.
A good beginning is half the battle.
A great ship asks for deep waters.
A hungry belly has no ears.
A living dog is better than a dead lion.
A luckless man is like incense without fire.
A man without enemies is like a river without stones.
A mild lamb sucks at two mothers.
A mountain does not meet another mountain, but man meets man.
A relative’s slap hurts more than a stranger’s.
A small log will overthrow a big cart.
A tent without a wife is like a fiddle without a string.
A well-turned lie pays better than the truth.
A woman without a husband is like a distaff without the spindle.
A young woman, like new wine, bubbles.
A  Stones will remain for ever while water passes.
Abundance, like want, ruins many.
Actions speak louder than words.
All complain of their lack of money, none of their want of brains.
All is well that ends well.
An ass is but an ass, even when laden with gold.
An old horse learns not to amble.
Before giving orders learn to submit yourself.
Better a crooked reconcilement than a straight judgment.
Better a man of straw than a woman of gold.
Better a sound donkey than a consumptive philosopher.
Better an egg today than an ox tomorrow.
Better be an eagle for a day than a rook for a whole year.
Better to ask twice than go wrong once.
Better to be a poor man’s son than the slave of a rich.
Borrowed clothes do not keep one warm.
By blackening another you do not whiten yourself.
Catch the thief before he catches you.
Choose a wife to please yourself, not others.
Cloth and a wife, choose them not at night.
Crows gather where the carrion lies.
Do not put your spoon into the pot which does not boil for you.
Do not send your wife alone to a wedding.
Do not set the mill on fire in order to burn the mice.
Do not wake the sleeping lion.
Dogs do not bark at a dead wolf.
Don’t argue with a fool, he has a rested mind.
Don’t give the sparrow in the hand for the crow on the fence.
Don’t leave for tomorrow, what you can do today.
Don’t measure others with your hand.
Don’t sell the fox skin in the wood.
Drink the wine, but not drunk by it.
Early risers travel far away.
Either act as you speak, or speak as you act.
Even a thread of hair has its shadow.
Even God gets out of a drunkard’s way.
Even God who is God cannot please all the world.
Even in paradise it is not pleasant to be alone.
Even the best of women has still a devil’s rib in her.
Even the devil cannot escape a woman.
Every bird dies by its own tongue.
Everything has a beginning.
Everything that flies is not good to eat.
For a lucky man the pot boils without fire.
For a sackful of learning a cartful of wisdom is needed.
From the truth to a lie is but a hand’s breadth.
God Before you find God, you are eaten by the saints.
God is great, but the devil is clever too.
God protect you from a woman’s judgment and a fool’s thrashing.
Good is rewarded with good.
Good wine and a pretty wife are two sweet poisons to a man.
He who burnt himself with soup blows also in the sour milk.
He who drinks on credit gets doubly drunk.
He who grudges the nail, loses the hoof.
He who mixes up with bran is eaten by pigs.
He who steals an egg today, will steal an ox tomorrow.
If a dog barks at you, stop his muzzle with bread.
If a friend is honey, do not try to eat all of him.
If the sun doesn’t come in through the window, the doctor will come in through the door.
If you are the anvil, suffer; if you are the hammer, strike.
If you only kept silent you would have passed for a wise man.
If you wish good advice, consult an old man.
Illness comes in a coach and goes away through the eye of a needle.
In a minstrel’s house everyone dances.
In the house where there are two girls, the cats die of thirst.
In unity lies strength.
In vain you show light to the blind.
It is easier to watch a flock of rabbits than a woman.
It is not good to be the driver of white horses or the servant of women.
It is one thing to promise and another to perform.
It’s the gentle cat that scratches the worst.
Justice is as the rulers make it … and as the people allow it.
Justice is as the rulers make it.
Kiss the hand you cannot bite.
Knotty timber must have sharp wedges.
Knowledge is power.
Let sleeping dogs lie.
Life is a waste if you didn’t live as you would have wanted to.
Little chips light great fires.
Little strokes fell great oaks.
Long absent, soon forgotten.
Look before you leap.
Love beyond measure afterwards brings hatred.
Love of money is the root of all evil.
Luck is like glass: when it starts to shine, it breaks.
Man consecrates the land.
Man has both life and death.
Man is like sheep: one readily follows after another.
Man’s life is like an egg in the hands of a child.
Many hands make light work.
Many see, few understand.
Money is round and rolls easily.
Money is the devil’s eye.
More than we use is more than we want.
My chicken is good, but my neighbor’s looks better.
Nakedness turns around; hunger goes straight.
No matter how far you have gone on a wrong road, turn back.
No matter how muddy the water, it will quench the fire.
No one takes money for thinking.
No one throws stones at a tree without fruit.
No sky without clouds.
Oil the wheels if you want the cart to run lightly.
One cannot make garments from cobwebs.
One fool creates a mess which ten wise men cannot undo.
One gather while the other one wastes.
One has no need of a guide to the village one can see.
One man laughs at another, and the devil at all.
One man’s mouth destroys cities.
One may become the devil’s brother in order to cross the bridge.
One who sits between two chairs may easily fall down.
One’s home is both paradise and hell.
Only fools are glad when governments change.
Put not pepper in other people’s meals.
Put not your nose in the pot which doesn’t boil for you.
Right goes with a broken head.
See the mother, and then marry the daughter.
Short love brings a long sigh.
Sin enters laughing and comes out crying.
Sit not idle, for your luck sits with you.
Small and great, we all boil in the same caldron.
Smoke and a scolding woman drive one out of the house.
Still waters run deep.
Strike while the iron is hot.
The anvil fears no blow.
The anvil fears no blows.
The apple falls under the apple tree.
The bear doesn’t dance for his own pleasure.
The blessing of having many children has never broken a man’s roof.
The chain is no stronger than its weakest link.
The cuckoo doesn’t sing until he sees the buds of spring.
The cuckoo sings while the lazy man sits and counts.
The dog barks at the moon all night long, but the moon never hears him.
The dogs bark and the caravan passes by…
The eagle does not catch flies.
The egg of a white hen is the same as that of a black one.
The estimate made at home does not hold good at the market.
The eye lets in love.
The fox is cunning, but more cunning is he who catches it.
The goat must browse where she is tied.
The house is burning and Grandma is combing her hair.
The husband doesn’t know what all the village knows.
The intoxication of youth surpasses that of wine.
The law turns on golden wheels.
The lawyers eat the kernel and the parties the shell of the nut.
The lie sinks like a plumb and comes up like a leaf.
The locust lives only a little while, but it does great damage.
The looking-glass is the enemy of ugly women.
The man who goes to law often loses an ox to win a cat.
The mounted man doesn’t believe the man that goes afoot.
The needle is small, but it sews costly garments.
The old dog doesn’t bark without reason.
The one who has a book, has the power.
The one who has knowledge, has four eyes.
The pearl lies at the bottom of the sea, while the corpse floats on the surface.
The rich man’s wealth swallows the morsel of the poor.
The road to hell is paved with good intentions.
The stairs are swept downwards, not upwards.
The sun rises whether the cock crows or not.
The sun warms the good man and bad man equally.
The village is burning and the granny is combing her hair.
The voice of the ass is not heard in heaven.
The wet man fears no rain.
The will is everything.
The wind gathers the clouds and the wind chases them away.
The wolf changes his fur, but never his habits.
The word of slander rings like a bell.
The worst wheel of a cart is the one that makes most noise.
The wound of a knife is easily healed, but the wound in the heart never.
There is no bitterer fruit than foreigners in one’s land.
There is no going to heaven in a sedan.
There is no such thing as a good husband or a sweet onion.
There is no wedding without laughter and no death without tears.
There is no wine without dregs.
There is no wise response to a foolish remark.
There is some respite from a barking dog, but never from wagging tongues.
There’s no smoke without fire.
Thieves increase with the making of new laws.
Thieves nowadays are not in the forests, but in the offices.
Thistle doesn’t catch in smooth cloth.
Three things are not to be lent: the horse, the gun. and the wife.
Throw the good to your left and right, and you’ll find it when you’ll need it.
Time ripens all things.
Truth lies at the bottom of the well.
Under a glove the ugliest hand is hidden.
Under a ragged coat lies wisdom.
Until the baby cries, the mother doesn’t give him suck.
Use your ears to listen, use your eyes to see, but use your mouth to shut up.
Virtue is its own reward.
Water flows, but rocks remain.
Wealth is like a pool: as soon as you dig a channel, it all runs out.
What can’t be cured must be endured.
What is born of a cat will catch mice.
What is everybody’s business is nobody’s business.
What the heart thinks, the tongue speaks.
When a thing is done, advice comes too late.
When it dries up, one knows the worth of the fountain.
When misfortune sleeps, beware of awakening it.
When nuns dance the devil does not weep.
When one pot hits another, both break.
When the cat is not at home the mice dance on the table.
When the devil grew old he became a monk.
When the head does not work, the legs suffer.
When the master is away the mice play on the table.
When you do good, you get good.
Where the liquor is in, the wit is out.
Where there are too many midwives, the baby is left with the umbilical cord uncut.
Where there is love, there is also a quarrel.
Where there is much learning, there is much folly too.
Where there is no head, woe to the feet.
Who flatters you has either cheated you or hopes to do so.
Who talks, sells; who listens, buys.
Who will eat the kernel of the nut must break the shell.
With money one can even buy rabbit cheese.
Woe to the house where the hen crows and the cock keeps silent.
Wolf doesn’t eat wolf.
Work has bitter roots, but sweet fruits.
Work is a golden bracelet.
Worse than the thief himself is the keeper of the thief.
Yesterday will not be called again.
You can’t straighten the world with your shoulder.
You do not know what is good until you lose it.
You need not look after the hoofs of dead horses.
Many heroes appear after the war.
Where defeat is inevitable, it is expedient to yield.
Even in paradise it is no fun to be alone.
Every sin brings its punishment with it.
When the head does not work, the legs suffer.
The thief who isn’t caught is an honest salesman.
Where the heart is willing it will find a thousand ways, but where it is unwilling it will find a thousand excuses.
A bean in liberty is better than a comfit in prison.
When sorrow is asleep, wake it not.
The rich man makes mistakes and the poor men get the blame.
A clear sky fears not the thunder.
The eyes have one language everywhere.
There’s no physician like a true friend.
Under a ragged coat lies wisdom.
Better an ugly duckling from your own village than a beauty from foreign parts.
The devil gives even rich men presents.
Even silence is an answer.
A creaking door hangs long on its hinges.
Nothing is more changeable than time and a woman.
Only fools are glad when governments change.
So long as you don’t step on a snail’s tail, he won’t get up and bite you.
One short step lengthens life.
A tent without a woman is like a violin with no strings.
A good bee will not go to a drooping flower.
Don’t try to sell pumpkins to a gardener.
If you lie upon roses when you’re young, you’ll lie upon thorns when you’re old.
If you are already wet, you won’t care about the rain.
An ass is but an ass, though laden with gold.
What does a donkey know about the life of a nightingale?
Better a healthy donkey than a consumptive philosopher.
When a liar speaks the truth, he is sick.
Call the bear uncle till you are safe across the bridge.
In a house where two daughters live, the cat dies of thirst.
Do not cut the bough you are sitting on.
If you want to sweep the steps clean, start at the top.
What the heart thinks, the tongue speaks.
Love understands all languages.
He who wants to talk with the dogs must learn to bark.
Beauty without wisdom is like a flower in the mud.
Kiss the hand that you cannot bite.
The blessing of having many children has never broken a man’s roof.
You don’t go into a tavern to say your prayers.
Make a pact with the devil until you have crossed the bridge.
Out of a devil’s egg there can only come a devil.
Acorns were good till bread was found.
When a thing is done, advice comes too late.
The hen that cackles in the evening lays no eggs in the morning.
Winter will ask you what you did during the summer.
A great ship asks for deep waters.
If you are travelling in the blind man’s country close one eye.
Complain about the house where the husband is the wife.
Adversity makes a man wise, not rich.
The man of many trades bakes his bread on Sunday.
A bad workman blames with his tools.
The man of many trades begs his bread on Sunday.
Where God has sown it shall flourish.
The man who takes legal action often loses an ox to win a cat.
A bad workman quarrels with his tools.
Eating and scratching want but a beginning.
Women have long skirts and short minds.
Gloves hide the ugliest hands.
Only what you have in your hand is not a lie.
My chicken is good, but my neighbor’s looks better.
Hunger goes in a straight line, desire turns in circles.
Before you find God, you will be eaten by saints.
A second marriage is like a warmed-up meal.
Before you make a friend, eat a bushel of salt with him.
He, who is afraid of death, loses his life.
The rich man makes mistakes and the poor men get the blame.
A bad workman quarrels with his tools.
Do not put your spoon into the pot which does not boil for you.
The luck of idle men sits next to them.
Better an egg today, than an ox tomorrow.
From fools, children and drunkards you get to hear the truth.
Your wife’s eyes are in your purse.
Small tree trunks can make the cart turn over.
The truth is told in jokes.
Mice always return to their own little holes.
Better a mouse in the pot than no meat at all.
The looking glass is the enemy of ugly women.
Look first at the mother and then the daughter.
A woman’s tongue is a double edged knife.
By proscription you give the face.
Knotty timber must have sharp wedges.
He who rises early goes far.
Don’t throw your blanket in the fire just because it has one flea in it.
The goat must browse where she is tied.
Use a little fish to catch a big.
Examples evil communications corrupt good manners.
The eyes which don’t see each other, forget each other.
Wait there roan, to graze green grass.
The snake bites the tamer first.
Take money from the dry well.
A barber learns to shave by shaving fools.
You should not add oil to the fire.
In at one ear and out at the other.
The Need forces you to do.
The way to hell is tiled with good meanings.
The fruit does not fall far from the tree.
One who sits between two chairs may easily fall down.
The lamp is not burning for those asleep.
In a hundred years we will be dead anyway.
The eagle does not catch flies.
Don’t leave for tomorrow what you can do today.
Good goods, cheap goods.
Fish and guests stink after three days.
Don’t give the sparrow in the hand for the crow on the fence.
Take an ox by its horns, a man by his heart.
There is no going to heaven in a sedan.
Each to his taste.
Choose a wife to please yourself, not others.
He, who is afraid of death, loses his life.
He that never rode never fell.
If you wish good advice, consult an old man.
Who digs a pit will himself fall therein.
Good wine needs no bush.
From the same wood you can make a cross or a club.
Without other people’s companionship, even paradise would be an unlikable place.
The tongue is not steel, yet it cuts.
Who chases two rabbits will get neither.
It is idle to swallow the cow and choke on the tail.
The wind does not paint red eggs.
Abundance, like want, ruins many.
A fair day in winter is the mother of a storm.
Short love, long sighs.
A foreigner scratches you where you do not itch.
When the fox preaches, look to the geese.
The calm water is down reaching.
Such mother, such daughter.
Who is silent leaves no regret.
There is no smoke without fire.
God gives the milk, but not the pail.
We choose the lesser of two evils.
The anvil fears no blows.
When you spit against the wind you get a dirty beard.
A blind man will not thank you for a looking glass.
The needle is small, but it sews expensive garments.
He gives double who gives quickly.
Such father, such son.
The tree makes shafts for axes.
Don’t sell the skin of the bear from the forest.
The lion won’t turn on a barking puppy.
